with a view more fully to ascertain the truth of these alle-
gations, the following experiments were made. 
Ex. 33. Two lenses between which a large & beautiful set of 
Newtonian rings were formed, were placed under the glass 
receiver of an excellent Air pump, & the Air exausted. it 
is certain that the colours were in no degree injured therby 
but might have been in a small degree improved  without its being perceived through the glass receiver, which must have 
interceted some of the rays; besides, the refrctive power of Air 
differs so little from that of vacu<s>o<\s>, that the effect of the change 
from one to the other might be nearly imperceptible. * 
Ex. 34. As the appearance or non appearance of coloured 
phenomena between the surfaces of glass plates or lenses were 
found to depend on intervals which were too minute to be mea-
sured by any common mode; I procured a few glass globes 
to be blown thin enough to show prismatic colours: and in 
the several experiments that were made for the above purposes, 
as well as for determining the limits beyond which coloured 
phenomena cease to appear, fragments of those globes were used 
as measures, which altho not easily reducible to parts of an inch, 
might serve to compare with each other. 
Ex. 35. It was found by repeated trials, that one of those 
fragments in thickness, was in most cases when interposed bet-
ween the surfaces, sufficient to prevent the appearance of 
primaries; but that two, & sometimes three in thickness, 
were necessary to prevent the appearance of Binaries. those 
differences might no doubt depend partly on the imperfection 
of even the best glass plates, as well as on the different thick-
ness of the fragments; but in all cases, a less thickness of 
these fragments were required to prevent the appearance 
of primaries, than that of Binaries. 
Ex. 36. Water when introduced between lenses where 
Newtonian rings were formed injured the colours but little.
